newsitem.title: USA: Household deal seen accretive in '98.
newsitem.headline: Household deal seen accretive in '98.

text.p: Household International Inc's planned purchase of the consumer finance business of Transamerica Corp is expected to be neutral to slightly accretive to 1997 earnings and to add $0.15 to $0.20 a share in 1998, analyst said.
Household officials were not available to comment or confirm the earnings estimates.
Analysts said Household's $1.1 billion acquisition will help it increase its network of consumer finance offices under the HFC brand.

"There is a certain type of consumer who doesn't like banks. Household International just acquired thousands of relationships with non-bank customers," Piper Jaffray analyst Jeff Evanson said. "That's the core customer that they want."
Household's primary business is HFC, the oldest consumer finance company in the United States. It also issues private label and general purpose credit cards.
Household shares traded up 3/8 at 92-1/4 and Transamerica's stock was down 1/8 at 87-1/8.
Duff & Phelps fixed income analyst Chris Reed said he believed the $1.1 billion reflected a "healthy premium" paid by Household for the Transamerica business.
"They definitely paid a healthy premium for what they acquired as reflected by the purchase price," Reed said. "There was extensive competition for the acquisition."
